indicators.justification:
A French colony since 1853, New Caledonia became a French Overseas Territory (TOM) from 1946. New Caledonia is entering the final phase of the self-determination process under the Noumea Accord(May 5, 1998) on the accession of New Caledonia to full sovereignty. This will be decided on December 12, 2021 following a 3rd self-determination referendum (1).

New Caledonia is an overseas collectivity with a special status. Its unique status results from the Nouméa Accord (3), approved during the electoral consultation of November 8, 1998. Organic law n ° 99-209 of March 19, 1999 sets the framework in which the development of the institution of New Caledonia will take place for twenty years. (2)

The Pacific Community (SPC) is an international government organisation that is owned and governed by its members states. New Caledonia is one of three Pacific island French associated territories which make up the 22 Pacific island countries and territories that govern the organisation. As an apolitical organisation, the SPC must remain neutral in matters relating to political governance within our member states. Given the politically sensitive time that New Caledonia is going through leading up to the referendum in December, SPC, as the commissioning organisation for the GDB survey in New Caledonia, has decided to refrain from responding to the questions under the Political Integrity module.




#REFERENCE
(1) https://www.elections-nc.fr/histoire/etapes-du-processus-institutionnel
(2) 'The tages of the Instututional Process' https://gouv.nc/gouvernement-et-institutions/en-un-coup-doeil
(3) Noumea Accord https://unterm.un.org/UNTERM/Display/record/UNHQ/__Noumea_Accord/9BCA7682FD6EEF7985257A85006D4AEB

evidence.title: Self-determination process on the accession of New Caledonia to full sovereignty

indicators.justification:
There are evidence of Government partial efforts to support data reuse.

The initiation of the government's open data program began in October 2019. An official public launch was held in July 2020. The government efforts to support reuse exists partially and will be improved in the next years. 
- (url 1) The governement's approach to open data is described on the web site 
- (url 2) Open licenses that encourage reuse without any restrictions (obligation to specify source)

Specifically 

1-Government efforts to support data reuse by the private sector. 
The Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCI) is a partner of Open DATA GOUV NC
Conferences organized by CCI Chamber of Commerce and Industry, government interventions to promote the government's open data platform and federate reuse. 
(Attached file 2) CCI the Chamber of Commerce and Industry Newsletter (p22)
(Attached file 3) CCI conference DINUM Pitch

2-Government efforts to support data reuse by scholars and academic institutions : 

Government and provincial geospatial agencies are actively involved in community advocacy events promoting the reuse of government spatial data. Examples include facilitating the 'Geomatique Club NC' events such as the annual national 'GIS Day'. These events attract participation from government, private sector, academic and research institutes and NGOs.
(url 3,4,5)

(url 2) https://www.etalab.gouv.fr/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/ETALAB-Licence-Ouverte-v2.0.pdf
(url 3) https://georep.nc/evenements/gis-day
(url 4) https://georep.nc/evenements/reunions-trimestrielles
(url 5) https://georep.nc/evenements/groupes-de-travail

indicators.justification:
There is evidence that the government is providing training to develop civil servants' data literacy and data skills.  Training is delivered primarily by a dedicated government organisation - the Institute of Public Administration Training (IFAP). Training is also occasionally delivered by external suppliers and experts from overseas.
Courses offered by IFAP cater for non-technical public servants, servants already working with data, including advanced training, training delivered covers specific technical topics for data centred roles.

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

indicators.justification:
A French colony since 1853, New Caledonia became a French Overseas Territory (TOM) from 1946. New Caledonia is entering the final phase of the self-determination process under the Noumea Accord(May 5, 1998) on the accession of New Caledonia to full sovereignty. This will be decided on December 12, 2021 following a 3rd self-determination referendum (1).

New Caledonia is an overseas collectivity with a special status. Its unique status results from the Nouméa Accord (3), approved during the electoral consultation of November 8, 1998. Organic law n ° 99-209 of March 19, 1999 sets the framework in which the development of the institution of New Caledonia will take place for twenty years. (2)

The Pacific Community (SPC) is an international government organisation that is owned and governed by its members states. New Caledonia is one of three Pacific island French associated territories which make up the 22 Pacific island countries and territories that govern the organisation. As an apolitical organisation, the SPC must remain neutral in matters relating to political governance within our member states. Given the politically sensitive time that New Caledonia is going through leading up to the referendum in December, SPC, as the commissioning organisation for the GDB survey in New Caledonia, has decided to refrain from responding to the questions under the Political Integrity module.

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification:
A French colony since 1853, New Caledonia became a French Overseas Territory (TOM) from 1946. New Caledonia is entering the final phase of the self-determination process under the Noumea Accord(May 5, 1998) on the accession of New Caledonia to full sovereignty. This will be decided on December 12, 2021 following a 3rd self-determination referendum (1).

New Caledonia is an overseas collectivity with a special status. Its unique status results from the Nouméa Accord (3), approved during the electoral consultation of November 8, 1998. Organic law n ° 99-209 of March 19, 1999 sets the framework in which the development of the institution of New Caledonia will take place for twenty years. (2)

The Pacific Community (SPC) is an international government organisation that is owned and governed by its members states. New Caledonia is one of three Pacific island French associated territories which make up the 22 Pacific island countries and territories that govern the organisation. As an apolitical organisation, the SPC must remain neutral in matters relating to political governance within our member states. Given the politically sensitive time that New Caledonia is going through leading up to the referendum in December, SPC, as the commissioning organisation for the GDB survey in New Caledonia, has decided to refrain from responding to the questions under the Political Integrity module.




#REFERENCE
(1) https://www.elections-nc.fr/histoire/etapes-du-processus-institutionnel
(2) 'The tages of the Instututional Process' https://gouv.nc/gouvernement-et-institutions/en-un-coup-doeil
(3) Noumea Accord https://unterm.un.org/UNTERM/Display/record/UNHQ/__Noumea_Accord/9BCA7682FD6EEF7985257A85006D4AEB

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding the number of requests submitted and processed.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding material withheld and the reasons for withholding it.
The framework requires the collection and publication of data regarding appeals to RTI determinations and their results.
The framework requires that information is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, government.
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, civil society
There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, the private sector.
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, media.

indicators.justification:
ADRAF publishes a report on land use every year. It is based on data made available by other institutions.

Land redistribution takes the form of land acquisition and allocation operations, mainly with a view to satisfying claims expressed in respect of the link to land.

Allocations of customary lands take place mainly for the benefit of groups of local special law (GLPL) and, occasionally, of the tribes.

Land tenure security. This post-allocation action constitutes a specific form of land development and a prerequisite for the valuation and development of customary lands. It translates into support for beneficiaries on all issues related to the organization of allocated land spaces (provision, rental, definition of plots, management of land disputes, etc.) and the internal organization of GLPLs.

indicators.justification:
The improvement of the procurement practice is one of the strategic axis of the government  : Axis 2 "government procurement and contracts".  
The legislation was adapted to ensure the improvement and civil servant was trained. Trainings of an important number of civil servant where organized (published in page 12)
Analysis and statistics are done allowing to improve based on KPI, they are published for all stage of the process as well as the amount by type and organization, actions ...) (published pages 13 to 15)

There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.

There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.

There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
